repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Food Crisis Response
            Operation Development Policy Operation

abstracts.cdata!:
Both loans that were approved for the
            Philippines in 2010, were the Food Crisis Response
            Development Policy Operation and the Supplemental Support
            for Post-Typhoon Recovery. They both resulted with a
            satisfactory outcome by both the Bank and borrower. The
            reasons for the loans were the sharp spike in global prices
            of rice followed by large purchase by the National Food
            Authority leaving the Philippines among one of the hardest
            countries to be hit in the region. Also in 2009 they
            experienced two major typhoons just weeks apart that caused
            substantial losses and damage in some of the countrys most
            economically vibrant regions. Some of the key lessons
            learned from the Development Policy Operation (DPO) were a
            pre-existing government or country owned agenda is critical
            to the effectiveness of the DPO. Also there are important
            potential synergies between DPOs and Specific Investment
            Loans (SIL) that can be exploited during program implements.
            Finally, that there is potential to leverage reforms in one
            sector, such as social protection to achieve reforms in
            another, such as agricultural reform.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Global Food Crisis Response
            Program Development Policy Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Global Food Crisis Response Program
            Development Policy Operation (DPO) Project will support the
            Government of the Philippines address the challenges of high
            food prices in the short and medium term, particularly by
            supporting measures to strengthen social protection and
            safety nets to protect poor and vulnerable households. The
            operation recognizes the efforts by the Government to
            stabilize the price of rice, the country's staple food,
            and to provide immediate assistance to the country's
            poor and vulnerable populations. It also supports
            intermediary steps to improve the efficacy of social safety
            net programs. The DPO is a stand-alone, single tranche
            operation that is being prepared under the World Bank's
            Global Food Response Program (GFRP) facility. It responds to
            the Government's request for quick disbursing budget
            support to help address unbudgeted expenditures stemming
            from rising food and fuel prices and the slowing economy.
            The fiscal impact of the food and fuel prices is estimated
            to be around 1 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) and
            it is on this basis that the government revised its plans
            mid-year from one of achieving a balanced budget position
            for 2008 to one of a fiscal deficit of that order. The DPO
            will be financing a portion of the higher financing deficit.
            Over the medium term, the Bank intends to continue the
            policy dialogue with Government to encourage a deliberate
            and coordinated approach to managing the on-going food price
            increase, to reduce the likelihood and impacts of future
            price spikes in particular by supporting the development of
            a social protection program and help to improve medium to
            long-term agricultural productivity. The Bank will deepen
            its support to the Government in this area with a future
            investment operation aimed at helping implement the
            Government's new Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) program.
